00004 namespace Sass {

00007   /*
00008                 This is the equivalent of ruby's Sass::Util.paths.
00009 
00010     # Return an array of all possible paths through the given arrays.
00011     #
00012     # @param arrs [NodeCollection<NodeCollection<Node>>]
00013     # @return [NodeCollection<NodeCollection<Node>>]
00014     #
00015     # @example
00016     #   paths([[1, 2], [3, 4], [5]]) #=>
00017     #     # [[1, 3, 5],
00018     #     #  [2, 3, 5],
00019     #     #  [1, 4, 5],
00020     #     #  [2, 4, 5]]
00021 
00022    The following is the modified version of the ruby code that was more portable to C++. You
00023    should be able to drop it into ruby 3.2.19 and get the same results from ruby sass.
00024 
00025     def paths(arrs)
00026         // I changed the inject and maps to an iterative approach to make it easier to implement in C++
00027       loopStart = [[]]
00028 
00029       for arr in arrs do
00030         permutations = []
00031         for e in arr do
00032           for path in loopStart do
00033             permutations.push(path + [e])
00034           end
00035         end
00036         loopStart = permutations
00037       end
00038     end
00039         */
00040   Node paths(const Node& arrs, Context& ctx) {
00041     To_String to_string(&ctx);
00042 
00043     Node loopStart = Node::createCollection();
00044     loopStart.collection()->push_back(Node::createCollection());
00045 
00046     for (NodeDeque::iterator arrsIter = arrs.collection()->begin(), arrsEndIter = arrs.collection()->end();
00047         arrsIter != arrsEndIter; ++arrsIter) {
00048 
00049       Node& arr = *arrsIter;
00050 
00051       Node permutations = Node::createCollection();
00052 
00053       for (NodeDeque::iterator arrIter = arr.collection()->begin(), arrIterEnd = arr.collection()->end();
00054         arrIter != arrIterEnd; ++arrIter) {
00055 
00056         Node& e = *arrIter;
00057 
00058         for (NodeDeque::iterator loopStartIter = loopStart.collection()->begin(), loopStartIterEnd = loopStart.collection()->end();
00059           loopStartIter != loopStartIterEnd; ++loopStartIter) {
00060 
00061           Node& path = *loopStartIter;
00062 
00063           Node newPermutation = Node::createCollection();
00064           newPermutation.plus(path);
00065           newPermutation.collection()->push_back(e);
00066 
00067           permutations.collection()->push_back(newPermutation);
00068         }
00069       }
00070 
00071       loopStart = permutations;
00072     }
00073 
00074     return loopStart;
00075   }
00076

00078         /*
00079   This is the equivalent of ruby sass' Sass::Util.flatten and [].flatten.
00080   Sass::Util.flatten requires the number of levels to flatten, while
00081   [].flatten doesn't and will flatten the entire array. This function
00082   supports both.
00083 
00084   # Flattens the first `n` nested arrays. If n == -1, all arrays will be flattened
00085   #
00086   # @param arr [NodeCollection] The array to flatten
00087   # @param n [int] The number of levels to flatten
00088   # @return [NodeCollection] The flattened array
00089 
00090   The following is the modified version of the ruby code that was more portable to C++. You
00091   should be able to drop it into ruby 3.2.19 and get the same results from ruby sass.
00092 
00093   def flatten(arr, n = -1)
00094     if n != -1 and n == 0 then
00095       return arr
00096     end
00097 
00098     flattened = []
00099 
00100     for e in arr do
00101       if e.is_a?(Array) then
00102         flattened.concat(flatten(e, n - 1))
00103       else
00104         flattened << e
00105       end
00106     end
00107 
00108     return flattened
00109   end
00110   */
00111   Node flatten(const Node& arr, Context& ctx, int n = -1) {
00112     if (n != -1 && n == 0) {
00113       return arr;
00114     }
00115 
00116     Node flattened = Node::createCollection();
00117 
00118     for (NodeDeque::iterator iter = arr.collection()->begin(), iterEnd = arr.collection()->end();
00119         iter != iterEnd; iter++) {
00120         Node& e = *iter;
00121 
00122       if (e.isCollection()) {
00123         Node recurseFlattened = flatten(e, ctx, n - 1);
00124         flattened.collection()->insert(flattened.collection()->end(), recurseFlattened.collection()->begin(), recurseFlattened.collection()->end());
00125       } else {
00126         flattened.collection()->push_back(e);
00127       }
00128     }
00129 
00130     return flattened;
00131   }
00132 }
